sub_topic: The Hausdorff dimension of the Cantor dust.
message_1: What is the Hausdorff dimension of the Cantor dust set in 2-dimensional space, when each iteration removes 1/3 of the previous segment length, and the initial segment has a length of 1?
message_2:
The Cantor dust set is a fractal, and its Hausdorff dimension can be calculated using the formula:

Hausdorff dimension (D) = log(N) / log(1 / r)

where N is the number of self-similar pieces in each iteration, and r is the scaling factor (the ratio of the size of each piece to the size of the original set).

In the case of the Cantor dust set in 2-dimensional space, each iteration removes 1/3 of the previous segment length, so the scaling factor r is 1/3. In each iteration, the set is divided into 4 self-similar pieces (2 in each dimension).

So, we can plug these values into the formula:

D = log(4) / log(1 / (1/3))
D = log(4) / log(3)

Using a calculator, we find that the Hausdorff dimension of the Cantor dust set in 2-dimensional space is approximately 1.26186.
